newsitem.title: USA: Clinton to ask FCC to study liquor ad limits.
newsitem.headline: Clinton to ask FCC to study liquor ad limits.

text.p: President Bill Clinton wants the Federal Communications Commission to review the possibility of banning or sharply curbing liquor advertisements on television, the White House said on Tuesday.

Clinton, at an event scheduled for 1:15 PM EST (1815 GMT), planned to express concern over last year's decision by the liquor industry to remove a voluntary policy against TV advertising, White House spokesman Mike McCurry said.

Asked why Clinton was seeking a FCC review of the matter, McCurry said: "Since it pertains to television advertising, that's the appropriate contact, and remember, all we're doing is asking them to look into the question."

Another White House official said Clinton would cast the issue as one of protecting young people from a potential health hazard. The president would ask the FCC to examine if the ads encouraged young people to try drinking, he said.
Clinton has previously advocated curbs on cigarette advertising as part of a concerted administration campaign to discourage young people from smoking.
